page.title: 01Sandwich;a Cinque Port Town.
page.content: Sandwich was a significant Mediaeval port. Gradual silting of the mouth of the River Stour and development of spits and sand dunes have led to the town's decline in importance. Marshy land around the dry town site has since been reclaimed as very fertile farm land. Sandwich and the nearby village of Worth command large areas of orchard and vegetable crops with extensive cattle grazing on low lying meadow land. The area surrounding this timber beamed town with its narrow, traffic choked streets is almost without relief. It is bounded in the north by the River Stour, to the west by the new by-pass road, and in the east by the sandy sea-side ridges of Royal St. George's Golf Links. Sandwich is now a tourist's haven.
